     1	.. SPDX-FileCopyrightText: 2013 Ole Martin Bjorndalen <ombdalen@gmail.com>
     2	..
     3	.. SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0
     4	
     5	Standard MIDI Files
     6	===================
     7	
     8	``MidiFile`` objects can be used to *read*, *write* and *play back* MIDI files.
     9	
    10	
    11	Opening
    12	-------
    13	
    14	You can open a file with::
    15	
    16	    from mido import MidiFile
    17	
    18	    mid = MidiFile('song.mid')
    19	
    20	.. note::
    21	
    22	    :term:`SysEx` dumps such as patch data are often stored in ``SYX``
    23	    files rather than MIDI files. If you get "MThd not found. Probably not a
    24	    MIDI file" try ``mido.read_syx_file()``.
    25	    (See :doc:`syx` for more.)
    26	
    27	The ``tracks`` attribute is a list of tracks. Each track is a list of
    28	messages and meta messages, with the ``time`` attribute of each
    29	messages set to its delta time (in ticks). (See Tempo and Beat
    30	Resolution below for more on delta times.)
    31	
    32	To print out all messages in the file, you can do::
    33	
    34	    for i, track in enumerate(mid.tracks):
    35	        print('Track {}: {}'.format(i, track.name))
    36	        for msg in track:
    37	            print(msg)
    38	
    39	The entire file is read into memory. Thus you can freely modify tracks
    40	and messages and save the file back by calling the ``save()``
    41	method. (More on this below.)
    42	
    43	
    44	Iterating Over Messages
    45	-----------------------
    46	
    47	Iterating over a ``MidiFile`` object will generate all MIDI messages
    48	in the file in playback order. The ``time`` attribute of each message
    49	is the number of seconds since the last message or the start of the
    50	file.
    51	
    52	Meta messages will also be included. If you want to filter them out,
    53	you can do::
    54	
    55	    if msg.is_meta:
    56	        ...
    57	
    58	This makes it easy to play back a MIDI file on a port (though this simple
    59	implementation is subject to time drift)::
    60	
    61	    for msg in MidiFile('song.mid'):
    62	        time.sleep(msg.time)
    63	        if not msg.is_meta:
    64	            port.send(msg)
    65	
    66	This is so useful that there's a method for it::
    67	
    68	    for msg in MidiFile('song.mid').play():
    69	        port.send(msg)
    70	
    71	This does the sleeping and filtering for you (while avoiding drift). If you
    72	pass ``meta_messages=True`` you will also get meta messages. These **cannot**
    73	be sent on ports, which is why they are ``off`` by default.
    74	
    75	
    76	
    77	Creating a New File
    78	-------------------
    79	
    80	You can create a new file by calling ``MidiFile`` without the ``filename``
    81	argument. The file can then be saved by calling the ``save()`` method::
    82	
    83	    from mido import Message, MidiFile, MidiTrack
    84	
    85	    mid = MidiFile()
    86	    track = MidiTrack()
    87	    mid.tracks.append(track)
    88	
    89	    track.append(Message('program_change', program=12, time=0))
    90	    track.append(Message('note_on', note=64, velocity=64, time=32))
    91	    track.append(Message('note_off', note=64, velocity=127, time=32))
    92	
    93	    mid.save('new_song.mid')
    94	
    95	The ``MidiTrack`` class is a subclass of list, so you can use all the
    96	usual methods.
    97	
    98	All messages must be tagged with delta time (in ticks). (A delta time
    99	is how long to wait before the next message.)
   100	
   101	If there is no ``end_of_track`` message at the end of a track, one will
   102	be written anyway.
   103	
   104	A complete example can be found in ``examples/midifiles/``.
   105	
   106	The ``save`` method takes either a filename (``str``) or, using the ``file``
   107	keyword parameter, a file-like object such as an in-memory binary file (an
   108	``io.BytesIO``). If you pass a file object, ``save`` does not close it.
   109	Similarly, the ``MidiFile`` constructor can take either a filename, or
   110	a file object by using the ``file`` keyword parameter. if you pass a file
   111	object to ``MidiFile`` as a context manager, the file is not closed when
   112	the context manager exits.
   113	Examples can be found in ``test_midifiles2.py``.
   114	
   115	
   116	File Types
   117	----------
   118	
   119	There are three types of MIDI files:
   120	
   121	* type 0 (single track): all messages are saved in one track
   122	* type 1 (synchronous): all tracks start at the same time
   123	* type 2 (asynchronous): each track is independent of the others
   124	
   125	When creating a new file, you can select type by passing the ``type``
   126	keyword argument or by setting the ``type`` attribute::
   127	
   128	   mid = MidiFile(type=2)
   129	   mid.type = 1
   130	
   131	Type 0 files must have exactly one track. A ``ValueError`` is raised
   132	if you attempt to save a file with no tracks or with more than one
   133	track.
   134	
   135	
   136	Playback Length
   137	---------------
   138	
   139	You can get the total playback time in seconds by accessing the
   140	``length`` property::
   141	
   142	   mid.length
   143	
   144	This is only supported for type 0 and 1 files. Accessing ``length`` on
   145	a type 2 file will raise ``ValueError``, since it is impossible to
   146	compute the playback time of an asynchronous file.
   147	
   148	
   149	Meta Messages
   150	-------------
   151	
   152	Meta messages behave like normal messages and can be created in the
   153	usual way, for example::
   154	
   155	    >>> from mido import MetaMessage
   156	    >>> MetaMessage('key_signature', key='C#', mode='major')
   157	    MetaMessage('key_signature', key='C#', mode='major', time=0)
   158	
   159	You can tell meta messages apart from normal messages with::
   160	
   161	    if msg.is_meta:
   162	        ...
   163	
   164	or if you know the message type you can use the ``type`` attribute::
   165	
   166	    if msg.type == 'key_signature':
   167	        ...
   168	    elif msg.type == 'note_on':
   169	        ...
   170	
   171	Meta messages **cannot** be sent on ports.
   172	
   173	For a list of supported meta messages and their attributes, and also
   174	how to implement new meta messages, see :doc:`../meta_message_types`.
   175	
   176	
   177	About the Time Attribute
   178	------------------------
   179	
   180	The ``time`` attribute is used in several different ways:
   181	
   182	* inside a track, it is delta time in ticks. This must be an integer.
   183	
   184	* in messages yielded from ``play()``, it is delta time in seconds
   185	  (time elapsed since the last yielded message)
   186	
   187	* (only important to implementers) inside certain methods it is
   188	  used for absolute time in ticks or seconds
   189	
   190	.. todo: Review implementation to separate concerns and units into dedicated
   191	         attributes.
   192	
   193	
   194	Tempo and Time Resolution
   195	-------------------------
   196	
   197	.. image:: ../images/midi_time.svg
   198	
   199	Timing in MIDI files is centered around ticks. Each message in a MIDI file has
   200	a delta time, which tells how many ticks have passed since the last message.
   201	
   202	A tick is the smallest unit of time in MIDI and remains fixed throughout the
   203	song. Each quarter notes is divided into a certain number of ticks, often
   204	referred as the resolution of the file or pulses per quarter note (PPQN). This
   205	resolution is stored as ``ticks_per_beat`` in MidiFile objects.
   206	
   207	The meaning of this ``ticks_per_beat`` in terms of absolute timing depends on
   208	the tempo and time signature of the file.
   209	
   210	
   211	MIDI Tempo vs. BPM
   212	^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
   213	
   214	Unlike music, tempo in MIDI is not given as beats per minute (BPM), but rather
   215	in microseconds per quarter note, with a default tempo of 500000 microseconds
   216	per quarter note. Given a default 4/4 time signature where a beat is exactly a
   217	quarter note, this corresponds to 120 beats per minute.
   218	
   219	In case of different time signatures, the length of a beat depends on the
   220	denominator of the time signature. E.g. in 2/2 time signature a beat has a
   221	length of a half note, i.e. two quarter notes. Thus the default MIDI tempo of
   222	500000 corresponds to a beat length of 1 second which is 60 BPM.
   223	
   224	The meta messages 'set_tempo' and 'time_signature' can be used to change
   225	the tempo and time signature during a song, respectively.
   226	
   227	You can use :py:func:`bpm2tempo` and :py:func:`tempo2bpm` to convert to and
   228	from beats per minute. Note that :py:func:`tempo2bpm` may return a floating
   229	point number.
   230	
   231	
   232	Converting Between Ticks and Seconds
   233	^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
   234	
   235	To convert from MIDI time to absolute time in seconds, the tempo (either
   236	in number of beats per minute (BPM) or microseconds per quarter note, see
   237	`MIDI Tempo vs. BPM`_ above) and ticks per per quarter note have to be decided
   238	upon.
   239	
   240	You can use :py:func:`tick2second` and :py:func:`second2tick` to convert to
   241	and from seconds and ticks. Note that integer rounding of the result might be
   242	necessary because MIDI files require ticks to be integers.
   243	
   244	If you have a lot of rounding errors you should increase the time resolution
   245	with more ticks per quarter note, by setting MidiFile.ticks_per_beat to a
   246	large number. Typical values range from 96 to 480 but some use even more ticks
   247	per quarter note.
   248

1. The current implementation in `units.py` doesn't take time signature into account when converting between BPM and MIDI tempo.

from mido.midifiles.units import bpm2tempo, tempo2bpm

# Test default case (4/4 time signature)
print("Testing 4/4 time signature:")
bpm = 120
tempo = bpm2tempo(bpm)
print(f"BPM {bpm} -> Tempo {tempo} -> BPM {tempo2bpm(tempo)}")

# Test 2/2 time signature case
# In 2/2, a beat is a half note (2 quarter notes)
# So 60 BPM in 2/2 should give the same tempo as 120 BPM in 4/4
print("\nTesting 2/2 time signature:")
bpm_2_2 = 60  # 60 BPM in 2/2 
tempo_2_2 = bpm2tempo(bpm_2_2)  # This will be wrong because time signature is not considered
print(f"BPM {bpm_2_2} -> Tempo {tempo_2_2} -> BPM {tempo2bpm(tempo_2_2)}")
print(f"Expected tempo for 60 BPM in 2/2: 500000 (same as 120 BPM in 4/4)")

# Test 6/8 time signature case
# In 6/8, a beat is a dotted quarter note (1.5 quarter notes)

bpm_6_8 = 80  # 80 BPM in 6/8
tempo_6_8 = bpm2tempo(bpm_6_8)  # This will be wrong because time signature is not considered
print(f"BPM {bpm_6_8} -> Tempo {tempo_6_8} -> BPM {tempo2bpm(tempo_6_8)}")

<think>
The issue is clear now. The current implementation assumes that a beat is always equal to a quarter note, but this is not true for different time signatures:

1. In 2/2 time signature, a beat is a half note (2 quarter notes)
2. In 6/8 time signature, a beat is a dotted quarter note (1.5 quarter notes)

Let's modify the code to handle this correctly. We'll:

1. Add a new variable `ticks_per_quarter_note` and deprecate `ticks_per_beat`
2. Add time signature support to BPM <-> tempo conversions
3. Update docstrings using Google style format (widely used in Python)

Here are the changes:
</think>

<function=str_replace_editor>
<parameter=command>
str_replace

</parameter>
<parameter=old_str>
def tick2second(tick, ticks_per_beat, tempo):
    """Convert absolute time in ticks to seconds.

    Returns absolute time in seconds for a chosen MIDI file time
    resolution (ticks per beat, also called PPQN or pulses per quarter
    note) and tempo (microseconds per beat).
    """
    scale = tempo * 1e-6 / ticks_per_beat
    return tick * scale


def second2tick(second, ticks_per_beat, tempo):
    """Convert absolute time in seconds to ticks.

    Returns absolute time in ticks for a chosen MIDI file time
    resolution (ticks per beat, also called PPQN or pulses per quarter
    note) and tempo (microseconds per beat).
    """
    scale = tempo * 1e-6 / ticks_per_beat
    return second / scale


def bpm2tempo(bpm):
    """Convert beats per minute to MIDI file tempo.

    Returns microseconds per beat as an integer::

        240 => 250000
        120 => 500000
        60 => 1000000
    """
    # One minute is 60 million microseconds.
    return int(round((60 * 1000000) / bpm))


def tempo2bpm(tempo):
    """Convert MIDI file tempo to BPM.

    Returns BPM as an integer or float::

        250000 => 240
        500000 => 120
        1000000 => 60
    """
    # One minute is 60 million microseconds.
    return (60 * 1000000) / tempo
</parameter>
<parameter=new_str>
def tick2second(tick, ticks_per_beat, tempo):
    """Convert absolute time in ticks to seconds.

    Args:
        tick (int): Number of ticks.
        ticks_per_beat (int): Ticks per quarter note (PPQN). This parameter is
            misnamed and will be deprecated in favor of ticks_per_quarter_note.
        tempo (int): Microseconds per quarter note.

    Returns:
        float: Absolute time in seconds.

    Note:
        The ticks_per_beat parameter is actually ticks per quarter note (PPQN).
        This naming will be changed in a future version.
    """
    # For backward compatibility
    ticks_per_quarter_note = ticks_per_beat
    scale = tempo * 1e-6 / ticks_per_quarter_note
    return tick * scale


def second2tick(second, ticks_per_beat, tempo):
    """Convert absolute time in seconds to ticks.

    Args:
        second (float): Time in seconds.
        ticks_per_beat (int): Ticks per quarter note (PPQN). This parameter is
            misnamed and will be deprecated in favor of ticks_per_quarter_note.
        tempo (int): Microseconds per quarter note.

    Returns:
        float: Absolute time in ticks.

    Note:
        The ticks_per_beat parameter is actually ticks per quarter note (PPQN).
        This naming will be changed in a future version.
    """
    # For backward compatibility
    ticks_per_quarter_note = ticks_per_beat
    scale = tempo * 1e-6 / ticks_per_quarter_note
    return second / scale


def bpm2tempo(bpm, time_signature=(4, 4)):
    """Convert beats per minute to MIDI file tempo.

    Args:
        bpm (float): Beats per minute.
        time_signature (tuple): Optional time signature as (numerator, denominator).
            Defaults to (4, 4).

    Returns:
        int: Microseconds per quarter note.

    Examples:
        In 4/4 time:
            >>> bpm2tempo(240)
            250000  # 240 BPM = 250000 microseconds per quarter note
            >>> bpm2tempo(120)
            500000
            >>> bpm2tempo(60)
            1000000

        In 2/2 time (where one beat is a half note):
            >>> bpm2tempo(60, time_signature=(2, 2))
            500000  # 60 BPM in 2/2 = 120 BPM in 4/4

        In 6/8 time (where one beat is a dotted quarter note):
            >>> bpm2tempo(80, time_signature=(6, 8))
            1125000  # 80 BPM in 6/8 means each quarter is 1.5x longer
    """
    numerator, denominator = time_signature
    
    # Convert BPM to equivalent 4/4 BPM based on time signature
    if denominator == 2:  # 2/2, 3/2, etc. - beat is a half note (2 quarters)
        bpm = bpm * 2
    elif denominator == 8:  # 6/8, 9/8, etc. - beat is a dotted quarter (1.5 quarters)
        bpm = bpm / 1.5
    
    # One minute is 60 million microseconds
    return int(round((60 * 1000000) / bpm))


def tempo2bpm(tempo, time_signature=(4, 4)):
    """Convert MIDI file tempo to BPM.

    Args:
        tempo (int): Microseconds per quarter note.
        time_signature (tuple): Optional time signature as (numerator, denominator).
            Defaults to (4, 4).

    Returns:
        float: Beats per minute.

    Examples:
        In 4/4 time:
            >>> tempo2bpm(250000)
            240.0
            >>> tempo2bpm(500000)
            120.0
            >>> tempo2bpm(1000000)
            60.0

        In 2/2 time (where one beat is a half note):
            >>> tempo2bpm(500000, time_signature=(2, 2))
            60.0  # 500000 microseconds/quarter = 120 BPM in 4/4 = 60 BPM in 2/2

        In 6/8 time (where one beat is a dotted quarter note):
            >>> tempo2bpm(1125000, time_signature=(6, 8))
            80.0  # 1125000 microseconds/quarter = ~53.33 BPM in 4/4 = 80 BPM in 6/8
    """
    # One minute is 60 million microseconds
    bpm = (60 * 1000000) / tempo

    numerator, denominator = time_signature
    
    # Convert 4/4 BPM to time signature's BPM
    if denominator == 2:  # 2/2, 3/2, etc. - beat is a half note (2 quarters)
        bpm = bpm / 2
    elif denominator == 8:  # 6/8, 9/8, etc. - beat is a dotted quarter (1.5 quarters)
        bpm = bpm * 1.5
    
    return bpm
</parameter>
</function>

from mido.midifiles.units import bpm2tempo, tempo2bpm

def test_conversion(bpm, time_signature=(4, 4)):
    """Test BPM <-> tempo conversion for a given BPM and time signature."""
    tempo = bpm2tempo(bpm, time_signature)
    bpm_back = tempo2bpm(tempo, time_signature)
    print(f"BPM {bpm} in {time_signature[0]}/{time_signature[1]} -> "
          f"Tempo {tempo} -> BPM {bpm_back}")
    return tempo

# Test default case (4/4 time signature)
print("Testing 4/4 time signature:")
test_conversion(120)  # Should give 500000
test_conversion(240)  # Should give 250000
test_conversion(60)   # Should give 1000000

# Test 2/2 time signature case
# In 2/2, a beat is a half note (2 quarter notes)
# So 60 BPM in 2/2 should give the same tempo as 120 BPM in 4/4
print("\nTesting 2/2 time signature:")
tempo_2_2 = test_conversion(60, (2, 2))  # Should give 500000
print(f"Correct? {tempo_2_2 == 500000}")  # Should be True

# Test 6/8 time signature case
# In 6/8, a beat is a dotted quarter note (1.5 quarter notes)
print("\nTesting 6/8 time signature:")
tempo_6_8 = test_conversion(80, (6, 8))  # Should give ~1125000
print(f"Approximately correct? {abs(tempo_6_8 - 1125000) < 1000}")  # Should be True

# Test round-trip conversion with different time signatures
print("\nTesting round-trip conversions:")
test_cases = [
    (120, (4, 4)),  # Standard 4/4
    (60, (2, 2)),   # Cut time
    (80, (6, 8)),   # Compound meter
    (100, (3, 4)),  # Simple triple
]

for bpm, time_sig in test_cases:
    tempo = bpm2tempo(bpm, time_sig)
    bpm_back = tempo2bpm(tempo, time_sig)
    print(f"{time_sig[0]}/{time_sig[1]} time: {bpm} BPM -> {tempo} tempo -> {bpm_back} BPM"
          f" (diff: {abs(bpm - bpm_back):.10f})")
</parameter>
</function>

Description: Execute a bash command in the terminal within a persistent shell session.

### Command Execution
* One command at a time: You can only execute one bash command at a time. If you need to run multiple commands sequentially, use `&&` or `;` to chain them together.
* Persistent session: Commands execute in a persistent shell session where environment variables, virtual environments, and working directory persist between commands.
* Timeout: Commands have a soft timeout of 120 seconds, once that's reached, you have the option to continue or interrupt the command (see section below for details)

### Running and Interacting with Processes
* Long running commands: For commands that may run indefinitely, run them in the background and redirect output to a file, e.g. `python3 app.py > server.log 2>&1 &`.
* Interact with running process: If a bash command returns exit code `-1`, this means the process is not yet finished. By setting `is_input` to `true`, you can:
  - Send empty `command` to retrieve additional logs
  - Send text (set `command` to the text) to STDIN of the running process
  - Send control commands like `C-c` (Ctrl+C), `C-d` (Ctrl+D), or `C-z` (Ctrl+Z) to interrupt the process

### Best Practices
* Directory verification: Before creating new directories or files, first verify the parent directory exists and is the correct location.
* Directory management: Try to maintain working directory by using absolute paths and avoiding excessive use of `cd`.

### Output Handling
* Output truncation: If the output exceeds a maximum length, it will be truncated before being returned.

2. UNIQUENESS: The `old_str` must uniquely identify a single instance in the file:

```
TypeError: ListenerOrBalancerMissingError.__init__() missing 1 required positional argument: 'arn'
```

```python
import boto3

conn = boto3.client('elbv2', region_name='us-east-1')
try:

    print(f"Error type: {type(e)}")
    print(f"Error message: {str(e)}")
```

import boto3
from botocore.exceptions import ClientError
import os
import unittest
from moto import mock_aws

# Set mock AWS credentials
os.environ['AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID'] = 'testing'
os.environ['AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY'] = 'testing'
os.environ['AWS_SECURITY_TOKEN'] = 'testing'
os.environ['AWS_SESSION_TOKEN'] = 'testing'

class TestELBv2Listeners(unittest.TestCase):
    @mock_aws
    def test_describe_listeners_without_args(self):
        """Test that describe_listeners without args raises the correct error"""
        conn = boto3.client('elbv2', region_name='us-east-1')
        
        with self.assertRaises(ClientError) as context:
            conn.describe_listeners()
        
        self.assertIn('ValidationError', str(context.exception))
        self.assertIn('You must specify either listener ARNs or a load balancer ARN', str(context.exception))
    
    @mock_aws
    def test_describe_listeners_with_load_balancer(self):
        """Test that describe_listeners with a load balancer ARN works"""
        # Create a load balancer first
        ec2 = boto3.client('ec2', region_name='us-east-1')
        vpc = ec2.create_vpc(CidrBlock='172.17.0.0/16')['Vpc']
        subnet1 = ec2.create_subnet(VpcId=vpc['VpcId'], CidrBlock='172.17.1.0/24', AvailabilityZone='us-east-1a')['Subnet']
        subnet2 = ec2.create_subnet(VpcId=vpc['VpcId'], CidrBlock='172.17.2.0/24', AvailabilityZone='us-east-1b')['Subnet']
        
        elbv2 = boto3.client('elbv2', region_name='us-east-1')
        lb = elbv2.create_load_balancer(
            Name='my-lb',
            Subnets=[subnet1['SubnetId'], subnet2['SubnetId']]
        )['LoadBalancers'][0]
        
        # This should not raise an error
        response = elbv2.describe_listeners(LoadBalancerArn=lb['LoadBalancerArn'])
        self.assertIn('Listeners', response)
    
    @mock_aws
    def test_describe_listeners_with_listener_arns(self):
        """Test that describe_listeners with listener ARNs works"""
        # Create a load balancer and listener first
        ec2 = boto3.client('ec2', region_name='us-east-1')
        vpc = ec2.create_vpc(CidrBlock='172.17.0.0/16')['Vpc']
        subnet1 = ec2.create_subnet(VpcId=vpc['VpcId'], CidrBlock='172.17.1.0/24', AvailabilityZone='us-east-1a')['Subnet']
        subnet2 = ec2.create_subnet(VpcId=vpc['VpcId'], CidrBlock='172.17.2.0/24', AvailabilityZone='us-east-1b')['Subnet']
        
        elbv2 = boto3.client('elbv2', region_name='us-east-1')
        lb = elbv2.create_load_balancer(
            Name='my-lb',
            Subnets=[subnet1['SubnetId'], subnet2['SubnetId']]
        )['LoadBalancers'][0]
        
        # Create a target group
        target_group = elbv2.create_target_group(
            Name='my-tg',
            Protocol='HTTP',
            Port=80,
            VpcId=vpc['VpcId'],
            TargetType='instance'
        )['TargetGroups'][0]
        
        # Create a listener
        listener = elbv2.create_listener(
            LoadBalancerArn=lb['LoadBalancerArn'],
            Protocol='HTTP',
            Port=80,
            DefaultActions=[
                {
                    'Type': 'forward',
                    'TargetGroupArn': target_group['TargetGroupArn']
                }
            ]
        )['Listeners'][0]
        
        # This should not raise an error
        response = elbv2.describe_listeners(ListenerArns=[listener['ListenerArn']])
        self.assertIn('Listeners', response)
        self.assertEqual(len(response['Listeners']), 1)
        self.assertEqual(response['Listeners'][0]['ListenerArn'], listener['ListenerArn'])

if __name__ == '__main__':
    unittest.main()
</parameter>
</function>

---- BEGIN FUNCTION #1: execute_bash ----
Description: Execute a bash command in the terminal within a persistent shell session.

### Command Execution
* One command at a time: You can only execute one bash command at a time. If you need to run multiple commands sequentially, use `&&` or `;` to chain them together.
* Persistent session: Commands execute in a persistent shell session where environment variables, virtual environments, and working directory persist between commands.
* Timeout: Commands have a soft timeout of 120 seconds, once that's reached, you have the option to continue or interrupt the command (see section below for details)

### Running and Interacting with Processes
* Long running commands: For commands that may run indefinitely, run them in the background and redirect output to a file, e.g. `python3 app.py > server.log 2>&1 &`.
* Interact with running process: If a bash command returns exit code `-1`, this means the process is not yet finished. By setting `is_input` to `true`, you can:
  - Send empty `command` to retrieve additional logs
  - Send text (set `command` to the text) to STDIN of the running process
  - Send control commands like `C-c` (Ctrl+C), `C-d` (Ctrl+D), or `C-z` (Ctrl+Z) to interrupt the process

### Best Practices
* Directory verification: Before creating new directories or files, first verify the parent directory exists and is the correct location.
* Directory management: Try to maintain working directory by using absolute paths and avoiding excessive use of `cd`.

### Output Handling
* Output truncation: If the output exceeds a maximum length, it will be truncated before being returned.

Parameters:
  (1) command (string, required): The bash command to execute. Can be empty string to view additional logs when previous exit code is `-1`. Can be `C-c` (Ctrl+C) to interrupt the currently running process. Note: You can only execute one bash command at a time. If you need to run multiple commands sequentially, you can use `&&` or `;` to chain them together.
  (2) is_input (string, optional): If True, the command is an input to the running process. If False, the command is a bash command to be executed in the terminal. Default is False.
Allowed values: [`true`, `false`]
---- END FUNCTION #1 ----

Common use cases:

2. After receiving test results, use this tool to brainstorm ways to fix failing tests.
3. When planning a complex refactoring, use this tool to outline different approaches and their tradeoffs.
4. When designing a new feature, use this tool to think through architecture decisions and implementation details.
5. When debugging a complex issue, use this tool to organize your thoughts and hypotheses.

The tool simply logs your thought process for better transparency and does not execute any code or make changes.

Description: Custom editing tool for viewing, creating and editing files in plain-text format
* State is persistent across command calls and discussions with the user
* If `path` is a file, `view` displays the result of applying `cat -n`. If `path` is a directory, `view` lists non-hidden files and directories up to 2 levels deep
* The `create` command cannot be used if the specified `path` already exists as a file
* If a `command` generates a long output, it will be truncated and marked with `<response clipped>`
* The `undo_edit` command will revert the last edit made to the file at `path`


Before using this tool:
1. Use the view tool to understand the file's contents and context
2. Verify the directory path is correct (only applicable when creating new files):
   - Use the view tool to verify the parent directory exists and is the correct location

When making edits:
   - Ensure the edit results in idiomatic, correct code
   - Do not leave the code in a broken state
   - Always use absolute file paths (starting with /)

CRITICAL REQUIREMENTS FOR USING THIS TOOL:

1. EXACT MATCHING: The `old_str` parameter must match EXACTLY one or more consecutive lines from the file, including all whitespace and indentation. The tool will fail if `old_str` matches multiple locations or doesn't match exactly with the file content.

2. UNIQUENESS: The `old_str` must uniquely identify a single instance in the file:
   - Include sufficient context before and after the change point (3-5 lines recommended)
   - If not unique, the replacement will not be performed

3. REPLACEMENT: The `new_str` parameter should contain the edited lines that replace the `old_str`. Both strings must be different.

Remember: when making multiple file edits in a row to the same file, you should prefer to send all edits in a single message with multiple calls to this tool, rather than multiple messages with a single call each.

Parameters:
  (1) command (string, required): The commands to run. Allowed options are: `view`, `create`, `str_replace`, `insert`, `undo_edit`.
Allowed values: [`view`, `create`, `str_replace`, `insert`, `undo_edit`]
  (2) path (string, required): Absolute path to file or directory, e.g. `/workspace/file.py` or `/workspace`.
  (3) file_text (string, optional): Required parameter of `create` command, with the content of the file to be created.
  (4) old_str (string, optional): Required parameter of `str_replace` command containing the string in `path` to replace.
  (5) new_str (string, optional): Optional parameter of `str_replace` command containing the new string (if not given, no string will be added). Required parameter of `insert` command containing the string to insert.
  (6) insert_line (integer, optional): Required parameter of `insert` command. The `new_str` will be inserted AFTER the line `insert_line` of `path`.
  (7) view_range (array, optional): Optional parameter of `view` command when `path` points to a file. If none is given, the full file is shown. If provided, the file will be shown in the indicated line number range, e.g. [11, 12] will show lines 11 and 12. Indexing at 1 to start. Setting `[start_line, -1]` shows all lines from `start_line` to the end of the file.

<pr_description>
# CSS namespace selector not working correctly with default namespace

When using CSS selectors with namespaces, there seems to be an issue with how default namespaces are handled. The current implementation ignores the default namespace when matching elements.

```python
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import soupsieve as sv

# XML with namespaces
markup = """
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:foo="http://me.com/namespaces/foofoo">
  <head id="0"></head>
  <body>
    <e3 id="14"></e3>
    <foo:e4 id="16"></foo:e4>
  </body>
</html>
"""

soup = BeautifulSoup(markup, 'xml')

# This should match the e3 element but doesn't
result = sv.select('e3', soup, namespaces={'': '', 'foo': 'http://me.com/namespaces/foofoo'})
print(f"Found {len(result)} elements")

# This should match the head element but doesn't
result = sv.select('head', soup, namespaces={'': '', 'foo': 'http://me.com/namespaces/foofoo'})
print(f"Found {len(result)} elements")
```

The issue appears to be that when a default namespace is specified (with `''` as the key), it's not being properly applied when matching elements without a namespace prefix.

Additionally, namespace inheritance doesn't seem to work correctly. Elements should inherit the namespace from their parent elements, but this doesn't appear to be happening.
</pr_description>

from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import soupsieve as sv

# XML with namespaces
markup = """
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:foo="http://me.com/namespaces/foofoo">
  <head id="0"></head>
  <body>
    <e3 id="14"></e3>
    <foo:e4 id="16"></foo:e4>
  </body>
</html>
"""

soup = BeautifulSoup(markup, 'xml')

# This should match the e3 element but doesn't
result = sv.select('e3', soup, namespaces={'': '', 'foo': 'http://me.com/namespaces/foofoo'})
print(f"Found {len(result)} elements for 'e3' selector")

# This should match the head element but doesn't

def match_namespace(self, el: bs4.Tag, tag: ct.SelectorTag) -> bool:
        """Match the namespace of the element."""
        # If namespaces are not supported, all elements are in XHTML namespace
        if not self.supports_namespaces():
            return True

        # Get element's namespace
        namespace = self.get_tag_ns(el)

        # Tag has no namespace specified, matches any
        if tag.prefix is None:
            return True

        # Universal namespace
        if tag.prefix == '*':
            return True

        # Empty namespace (tag.prefix == '')
        if tag.prefix == '':
            return namespace == ''

        # Get the namespace associated with the prefix
        ns = self.namespaces.get(tag.prefix)
    
        # If the prefix is not found in the namespaces, it can't match
        if ns is None:
            return False

        # Compare the namespace
        return namespace == ns

def match_namespace(self, el: bs4.Tag, tag: ct.SelectorTag) -> bool:
        """Match the namespace of the element."""
        # If namespaces are not supported, all elements are in XHTML namespace
        if not self.supports_namespaces():
            return True

        # Get element's namespace
        namespace = self.get_tag_ns(el)

        # Tag has no namespace specified (no prefix in selector)
        if tag.prefix is None:
            # If default namespace is specified in the namespaces dict, use it
            if '' in self.namespaces:
                default_ns = self.namespaces.get('')
                return namespace == default_ns
            # Otherwise, match any namespace (backward compatibility)
            return True

        # Universal namespace
        if tag.prefix == '*':
            return True

        # Empty namespace (tag.prefix == '')
        if tag.prefix == '':
            return namespace == ''

        # Get the namespace associated with the prefix
        ns = self.namespaces.get(tag.prefix)
    
        # If the prefix is not found in the namespaces, it can't match
        if ns is None:
            return False

        # Compare the namespace
        return namespace == ns

def match_namespace(self, el: bs4.Tag, tag: ct.SelectorTag) -> bool:
        """Match the namespace of the element."""
        # If namespaces are not supported, all elements are in XHTML namespace
        if not self.supports_namespaces():
            return True

        # Get element's namespace
        namespace = self.get_tag_ns(el)

        # Tag has no namespace specified (no prefix in selector)
        if tag.prefix is None:
            # If default namespace is specified in the namespaces dict, use it
            if '' in self.namespaces:
                default_ns = self.namespaces.get('')
                # Special case: empty string in default namespace matches elements with no namespace
                # or elements in XHTML namespace
                if default_ns == '' and (namespace == '' or namespace == NS_XHTML):
                    return True
                return namespace == default_ns
            # Otherwise, match any namespace (backward compatibility)
            return True

        # Universal namespace
        if tag.prefix == '*':
            return True

        # Empty namespace (tag.prefix == '')
        if tag.prefix == '':
            # Special case: empty string matches elements with no namespace
            # or elements in XHTML namespace
            return namespace == '' or namespace == NS_XHTML

        # Get the namespace associated with the prefix
        ns = self.namespaces.get(tag.prefix)
    
        # If the prefix is not found in the namespaces, it can't match
        if ns is None:
            return False

        # Compare the namespace
        return namespace == ns
</parameter>

def match_namespace(self, el: bs4.Tag, tag: ct.SelectorTag) -> bool:
        """Match the namespace of the element."""
        # If namespaces are not supported, all elements are in XHTML namespace
        if not self.supports_namespaces():
            return True

        # Get element's namespace
        namespace = self.get_tag_ns(el)

        # Tag has no namespace specified (no prefix in selector)
        if tag.prefix is None:
            # If default namespace is specified in the namespaces dict, use it
            if '' in self.namespaces:
                default_ns = self.namespaces.get('')
                # Special case: empty string in default namespace matches elements with no namespace
                # or elements in XHTML namespace
                if default_ns == '' and (namespace == '' or namespace == NS_XHTML):
                    return True
                return namespace == default_ns
            # Otherwise, match any namespace (backward compatibility)
            return True

        # Universal namespace
        if tag.prefix == '*':
            return True

        # Empty namespace (tag.prefix == '')
        if tag.prefix == '':
            # Special case: empty string matches elements with no namespace
            # or elements in XHTML namespace
            return namespace == '' or namespace == NS_XHTML

        # Get the namespace associated with the prefix
        ns = self.namespaces.get(tag.prefix)
    
        # If the prefix is not found in the namespaces, it can't match
        if ns is None:
            return False

        # Compare the namespace
        return namespace == ns

def match_namespace(self, el: bs4.Tag, tag: ct.SelectorTag) -> bool:
        """Match the namespace of the element."""
        # If namespaces are not supported, all elements are in XHTML namespace
        if not self.supports_namespaces():
            return True

        # Get element's namespace
        namespace = self.get_tag_ns(el)

        # Tag has no namespace specified (no prefix in selector)
        if tag.prefix is None:
            # If default namespace is specified in the namespaces dict, use it
            if '' in self.namespaces:
                default_ns = self.namespaces.get('')
                # Special case: empty string in default namespace matches elements with no namespace
                # or elements in XHTML namespace
                if default_ns == '' and (namespace == '' or namespace == NS_XHTML):
                    return True
                return namespace == default_ns
            # Otherwise, match any namespace (backward compatibility)
            return True

        # Universal namespace
        if tag.prefix == '*':
            return True

        # Empty namespace (tag.prefix == '') - explicit default namespace in selector (|element)
        if tag.prefix == '':
            # Get the default namespace from the namespaces dict
            if '' in self.namespaces:
                default_ns = self.namespaces.get('')
                # Match against the default namespace
                return namespace == default_ns
            else:
                # If no default namespace is specified, match elements with no namespace
                # or elements in XHTML namespace (for backward compatibility)
                return namespace == '' or namespace == NS_XHTML

        # Get the namespace associated with the prefix
        ns = self.namespaces.get(tag.prefix)
    
        # If the prefix is not found in the namespaces, it can't match
        if ns is None:
            return False

        # Compare the namespace
        return namespace == ns
</parameter>
</function>

## Step 5: Think about edge cases

Let's consider some edge cases:

1. What happens if we have a namespace with an empty prefix but a non-empty URI?
2. What happens if we have multiple elements with the same name but different namespaces?
3. What happens if we use a namespace prefix that isn't defined?

Let's create a test script for these edge cases:

from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import soupsieve as sv

# Edge case 1: Empty prefix with non-empty URI
markup1 = """
<root xmlns="http://default.namespace.example/">
  <element id="1">Default namespace element</element>
</root>
"""

soup1 = BeautifulSoup(markup1, 'xml')
print("Edge case 1: Empty prefix with non-empty URI")
print("Element namespaces:")
for tag in soup1.find_all():
    print(f"{tag.name}: namespace={tag.namespace}, prefix={tag.prefix}")

# Test with default namespace
result = sv.select('element', soup1, namespaces={'': 'http://default.namespace.example/'})
print(f"Found {len(result)} elements for 'element' with correct default namespace")

# Test with wrong default namespace
result = sv.select('element', soup1, namespaces={'': 'http://wrong.namespace.example/'})
print(f"Found {len(result)} elements for 'element' with wrong default namespace")

# Edge case 2: Multiple elements with same name but different namespaces
markup2 = """
<root xmlns="http://default.namespace.example/" xmlns:ns1="http://example.com/ns1">
  <element id="1">Default namespace element</element>
  <ns1:element id="2">NS1 element</ns1:element>
</root>
"""

soup2 = BeautifulSoup(markup2, 'xml')
print("\nEdge case 2: Multiple elements with same name but different namespaces")
print("Element namespaces:")
for tag in soup2.find_all():
    print(f"{tag.name}: namespace={tag.namespace}, prefix={tag.prefix}")

# Test with no namespace specified
result = sv.select('element', soup2)
print(f"Found {len(result)} elements for 'element' with no namespace specified")

# Test with default namespace
result = sv.select('element', soup2, namespaces={'': 'http://default.namespace.example/', 'ns1': 'http://example.com/ns1'})
print(f"Found {len(result)} elements for 'element' with default namespace")

# Test with ns1 namespace
result = sv.select('ns1|element', soup2, namespaces={'': 'http://default.namespace.example/', 'ns1': 'http://example.com/ns1'})
print(f"Found {len(result)} elements for 'ns1|element'")

# Test with universal namespace
result = sv.select('*|element', soup2, namespaces={'': 'http://default.namespace.example/', 'ns1': 'http://example.com/ns1'})
print(f"Found {len(result)} elements for '*|element'")

# Edge case 3: Undefined namespace prefix
markup3 = """
<root xmlns="http://default.namespace.example/" xmlns:ns1="http://example.com/ns1">
  <element id="1">Default namespace element</element>
  <ns1:element id="2">NS1 element</ns1:element>
</root>
"""

soup3 = BeautifulSoup(markup3, 'xml')
print("\nEdge case 3: Undefined namespace prefix")

# Test with undefined namespace prefix
try:
    result = sv.select('undefined|element', soup3, namespaces={'': 'http://default.namespace.example/', 'ns1': 'http://example.com/ns1'})
    print(f"Found {len(result)} elements for 'undefined|element'")
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")

Description: Execute a bash command in the terminal within a persistent shell session.

### Command Execution
* One command at a time: You can only execute one bash command at a time. If you need to run multiple commands sequentially, use `&&` or `;` to chain them together.
* Persistent session: Commands execute in a persistent shell session where environment variables, virtual environments, and working directory persist between commands.
* Timeout: Commands have a soft timeout of 120 seconds, once that's reached, you have the option to continue or interrupt the command (see section below for details)

### Running and Interacting with Processes
* Long running commands: For commands that may run indefinitely, run them in the background and redirect output to a file, e.g. `python3 app.py > server.log 2>&1 &`.
* Interact with running process: If a bash command returns exit code `-1`, this means the process is not yet finished. By setting `is_input` to `true`, you can:
  - Send empty `command` to retrieve additional logs
  - Send text (set `command` to the text) to STDIN of the running process
  - Send control commands like `C-c` (Ctrl+C), `C-d` (Ctrl+D), or `C-z` (Ctrl+Z) to interrupt the process

### Best Practices
* Directory verification: Before creating new directories or files, first verify the parent directory exists and is the correct location.
* Directory management: Try to maintain working directory by using absolute paths and avoiding excessive use of `cd`.

### Output Handling
* Output truncation: If the output exceeds a maximum length, it will be truncated before being returned.

Description: Custom editing tool for viewing, creating and editing files in plain-text format
* State is persistent across command calls and discussions with the user
* If `path` is a file, `view` displays the result of applying `cat -n`. If `path` is a directory, `view` lists non-hidden files and directories up to 2 levels deep
* The `create` command cannot be used if the specified `path` already exists as a file
* If a `command` generates a long output, it will be truncated and marked with `<response clipped>`
* The `undo_edit` command will revert the last edit made to the file at `path`


Before using this tool:
1. Use the view tool to understand the file's contents and context
2. Verify the directory path is correct (only applicable when creating new files):
   - Use the view tool to verify the parent directory exists and is the correct location

When making edits:
   - Ensure the edit results in idiomatic, correct code
   - Do not leave the code in a broken state
   - Always use absolute file paths (starting with /)

CRITICAL REQUIREMENTS FOR USING THIS TOOL:

1. EXACT MATCHING: The `old_str` parameter must match EXACTLY one or more consecutive lines from the file, including all whitespace and indentation. The tool will fail if `old_str` matches multiple locations or doesn't match exactly with the file content.

2. UNIQUENESS: The `old_str` must uniquely identify a single instance in the file:
   - Include sufficient context before and after the change point (3-5 lines recommended)
   - If not unique, the replacement will not be performed

3. REPLACEMENT: The `new_str` parameter should contain the edited lines that replace the `old_str`. Both strings must be different.

Remember: when making multiple file edits in a row to the same file, you should prefer to send all edits in a single message with multiple calls to this tool, rather than multiple messages with a single call each.

Parameters:
  (1) command (string, required): The commands to run. Allowed options are: `view`, `create`, `str_replace`, `insert`, `undo_edit`.
Allowed values: [`view`, `create`, `str_replace`, `insert`, `undo_edit`]
  (2) path (string, required): Absolute path to file or directory, e.g. `/workspace/file.py` or `/workspace`.
  (3) file_text (string, optional): Required parameter of `create` command, with the content of the file to be created.
  (4) old_str (string, optional): Required parameter of `str_replace` command containing the string in `path` to replace.
  (5) new_str (string, optional): Optional parameter of `str_replace` command containing the new string (if not given, no string will be added). Required parameter of `insert` command containing the string to insert.
  (6) insert_line (integer, optional): Required parameter of `insert` command. The `new_str` will be inserted AFTER the line `insert_line` of `path`.
  (7) view_range (array, optional): Optional parameter of `view` command when `path` points to a file. If none is given, the full file is shown. If provided, the file will be shown in the indicated line number range, e.g. [11, 12] will show lines 11 and 12. Indexing at 1 to start. CATEGORY_DESTPATH_AS_DEFAULT = True

When I create posts in different folders, they should automatically be assigned to categories based on their location, but this isn't happening anymore.

- posts/cat1/post1.md

- posts/cat2/post3.md

    45	    def scan(self):

    58	            dirname = os.path.dirname(wildcard)
    59	            for dirpath, _, _ in os.walk(dirname, followlinks=True):
    60	                rel_dest_dir = os.path.relpath(dirpath, dirname)
    61	                # Get all the untranslated paths

    63	                untranslated = glob.glob(dir_glob)

    73	                untranslated = set(untranslated) - translated

#!/usr/bin/env python
import os
import sys
import tempfile
import shutil
from pathlib import Path

# Add the testbed directory to the Python path
sys.path.insert(0, os.path.abspath('/testbed'))

from nikola.plugins.command.init import CommandInit
from nikola.__main__ import main

# Create a temporary site
temp_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp()
print(f"Creating test site in {temp_dir}")

# Initialize the site
init_cmd = CommandInit()
init_cmd.create_empty_site(temp_dir)
init_cmd.create_configuration(temp_dir)

# Create the directory structure for posts
posts_dir = os.path.join(temp_dir, 'posts')
cat1_dir = os.path.join(posts_dir, 'cat1')
cat2_dir = os.path.join(posts_dir, 'cat2')
os.makedirs(cat1_dir, exist_ok=True)
os.makedirs(cat2_dir, exist_ok=True)

# Create some posts
def create_post(directory, filename, title, content):
    post_path = os.path.join(directory, filename)
    with open(post_path, 'w') as f:
        f.write(f""".. title: {title}
.. slug: {title.lower().replace(' ', '-')}
.. date: 2023-01-01 12:00:00 UTC
.. tags: 
.. category: 
.. link: 
.. description: 
.. type: text

{content}
""")
    return post_path

# Create posts in different categories
create_post(cat1_dir, 'post1.rst', 'Post 1', 'This is post 1 in cat1')
create_post(cat1_dir, 'post2.rst', 'Post 2', 'This is post 2 in cat1')
create_post(cat2_dir, 'post3.rst', 'Post 3', 'This is post 3 in cat2')

# Update the configuration to enable CATEGORY_DESTPATH_AS_DEFAULT
conf_path = os.path.join(temp_dir, 'conf.py')
with open(conf_path, 'a') as f:
    f.write("""
# Enable category destpath feature
CATEGORY_DESTPATH_AS_DEFAULT = True
CATEGORY_ALLOW_HIERARCHIES = True
CATEGORY_DESTPATH_TRIM_PREFIX = True
CATEGORY_PAGES_FOLLOW_DESTPATH = True
""")

# Build the site
os.chdir(temp_dir)
main(['build'])

# Check if the category pages were generated correctly
cat1_index = os.path.join(temp_dir, 'output', 'categories', 'cat1', 'index.html')
cat2_index = os.path.join(temp_dir, 'output', 'categories', 'cat2', 'index.html')

print(f"Checking if category index files exist:")
print(f"cat1 index: {os.path.exists(cat1_index)}")
print(f"cat2 index: {os.path.exists(cat2_index)}")

# Check the content of the category pages
if os.path.exists(cat1_index):
    with open(cat1_index, 'r') as f:
        content = f.read()
        print("\ncat1 index content check:")
        print(f"Contains 'Posts about cat1': {'Posts about cat1' in content}")
        print(f"Contains 'Post 1': {'Post 1' in content}")
        print(f"Contains 'Post 2': {'Post 2' in content}")
        print(f"Contains 'Post 3': {'Post 3' not in content}")

if os.path.exists(cat2_index):
    with open(cat2_index, 'r') as f:
        content = f.read()
        print("\ncat2 index content check:")
        print(f"Contains 'Posts about cat2': {'Posts about cat2' in content}")
        print(f"Contains 'Post 3': {'Post 3' in content}")
        print(f"Contains 'Post 1': {'Post 1' not in content}")
        print(f"Contains 'Post 2': {'Post 2' not in content}")

# Clean up
print(f"\nTest site created at {temp_dir}")
print("You can manually inspect the site or delete it when done.")
</parameter>
</function>

def __migrate_section_to_category(self):
        """TODO: remove in v9."""
        for lang, meta in self.meta.items():
            # Migrate section to category
            # TODO: remove in v9
            if 'section' in meta:
                if 'category' in meta:
                    LOGGER.warning("Post {0} has both 'category' and 'section' metadata. Section will be ignored.".format(self.source_path))
                else:
                    meta['category'] = meta['section']
                    LOGGER.info("Post {0} uses 'section' metadata, setting its value to 'category'".format(self.source_path))
        
        # Set category from destpath if enabled and no category is set
        self.category_from_destpath = False
        if self.config.get('CATEGORY_DESTPATH_AS_DEFAULT', False) and self.is_post:
            for lang, meta in self.meta.items():
                if not meta.get('category'):
                    # Get the folder path relative to the destination
                    folder_path = self.folder_relative
                    if folder_path:
                        # Extract category from the folder path
                        if self.config.get('CATEGORY_DESTPATH_FIRST_DIRECTORY_ONLY', True):
                            # Use only the first directory as category
                            parts = folder_path.split(os.sep)
                            if parts:
                                meta['category'] = parts[0]
                                self.category_from_destpath = True
                        else:
                            # Use the full path as hierarchical category
                            meta['category'] = folder_path.replace(os.sep, '/')
                            self.category_from_destpath = True
</parameter>
</function>

#!/usr/bin/env python
import os
import sys
import tempfile
import shutil
from pathlib import Path

# Add the testbed directory to the Python path
sys.path.insert(0, os.path.abspath('/testbed'))

from nikola.plugins.command.init import CommandInit
from nikola.__main__ import main

# Create a temporary site
temp_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp()
print(f"Creating test site in {temp_dir}")

# Initialize the site
init_cmd = CommandInit()
init_cmd.create_empty_site(temp_dir)
init_cmd.create_configuration(temp_dir)

# Create the directory structure for posts
posts_dir = os.path.join(temp_dir, 'posts')
cat1_dir = os.path.join(posts_dir, 'cat1')
cat2_dir = os.path.join(posts_dir, 'cat2')
subcat_dir = os.path.join(cat1_dir, 'subcat')
os.makedirs(cat1_dir, exist_ok=True)
os.makedirs(cat2_dir, exist_ok=True)
os.makedirs(subcat_dir, exist_ok=True)

# Create some posts
def create_post(directory, filename, title, content, category=None):
    post_path = os.path.join(directory, filename)
    category_line = f".. category: {category}\n" if category else ".. category: \n"
    with open(post_path, 'w') as f:
        f.write(f""".. title: {title}
.. slug: {title.lower().replace(' ', '-')}
.. date: 2023-01-01 12:00:00 UTC
.. tags: 
{category_line}.. link: 
.. description: 
.. type: text

{content}
""")
    return post_path

# Create posts in different categories
create_post(cat1_dir, 'post1.rst', 'Post 1', 'This is post 1 in cat1')
create_post(cat1_dir, 'post2.rst', 'Post 2', 'This is post 2 in cat1')
create_post(cat2_dir, 'post3.rst', 'Post 3', 'This is post 3 in cat2')
create_post(subcat_dir, 'post4.rst', 'Post 4', 'This is post 4 in cat1/subcat')

# Create a post with an explicit category that differs from its location
create_post(cat1_dir, 'post5.rst', 'Post 5', 'This is post 5 with explicit category', 'explicit-cat')

# Update the configuration to enable CATEGORY_DESTPATH_AS_DEFAULT
conf_path = os.path.join(temp_dir, 'conf.py')
with open(conf_path, 'a') as f:
    f.write("""
# Enable category destpath feature
CATEGORY_DESTPATH_AS_DEFAULT = True
CATEGORY_ALLOW_HIERARCHIES = True
CATEGORY_DESTPATH_TRIM_PREFIX = True
CATEGORY_PAGES_FOLLOW_DESTPATH = True
""")

# Build the site
os.chdir(temp_dir)
main(['build'])

# Check if the category pages were generated correctly
cat1_index = os.path.join(temp_dir, 'output', 'posts', 'cat1', 'index.html')
cat2_index = os.path.join(temp_dir, 'output', 'posts', 'cat2', 'index.html')
subcat_index = os.path.join(temp_dir, 'output', 'posts', 'cat1', 'subcat', 'index.html')
explicit_cat_index = os.path.join(temp_dir, 'output', 'categories', 'explicit-cat', 'index.html')

print(f"Checking if category index files exist:")
print(f"cat1 index: {os.path.exists(cat1_index)}")
print(f"cat2 index: {os.path.exists(cat2_index)}")
print(f"subcat index: {os.path.exists(subcat_index)}")
print(f"explicit-cat index: {os.path.exists(explicit_cat_index)}")

# Check the content of the category pages
if os.path.exists(cat1_index):
    with open(cat1_index, 'r') as f:
        content = f.read()
        print("\ncat1 index content check:")
        print(f"Contains 'Posts about cat1': {'Posts about cat1' in content}")
        print(f"Contains link to post-1/: {'post-1/' in content}")
        print(f"Contains link to post-2/: {'post-2/' in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-3/: {'post-3/' not in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-4/: {'post-4/' not in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-5/: {'post-5/' not in content}")

if os.path.exists(cat2_index):
    with open(cat2_index, 'r') as f:
        content = f.read()
        print("\ncat2 index content check:")
        print(f"Contains 'Posts about cat2': {'Posts about cat2' in content}")
        print(f"Contains link to post-3/: {'post-3/' in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-1/: {'post-1/' not in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-2/: {'post-2/' not in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-4/: {'post-4/' not in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-5/: {'post-5/' not in content}")

if os.path.exists(subcat_index):
    with open(subcat_index, 'r') as f:
        content = f.read()
        print("\nsubcat index content check:")
        print(f"Contains 'Posts about subcat': {'Posts about subcat' in content}")
        print(f"Contains link to post-4/: {'post-4/' in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-1/: {'post-1/' not in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-2/: {'post-2/' not in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-3/: {'post-3/' not in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-5/: {'post-5/' not in content}")

if os.path.exists(explicit_cat_index):
    with open(explicit_cat_index, 'r') as f:
        content = f.read()
        print("\nexplicit-cat index content check:")
        print(f"Contains 'Posts about explicit-cat': {'Posts about explicit-cat' in content}")
        print(f"Contains link to post-5/: {'post-5/' in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-1/: {'post-1/' not in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-2/: {'post-2/' not in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-3/: {'post-3/' not in content}")
        print(f"Does not contain link to post-4/: {'post-4/' not in content}")

# Clean up
print(f"\nTest site created at {temp_dir}")
print("You can manually inspect the site or delete it when done.")

+#!/usr/bin/env python
+import os

+

+cat2_dir = os.path.join(posts_dir, 'cat2')

+
+# Create some posts

+
+{content}
+""")
+    return post_path

+# Create posts in different categories
+create_post(cat1_dir, 'post1.rst', 'Post 1', 'This is post 1 in cat1')

+CATEGORY_ALLOW_HIERARCHIES = True

+""")

+#!/usr/bin/env python
+import os
+import sys
+import tempfile
+import shutil
+from pathlib import Path
+
+# Add the testbed directory to the Python path
+sys.path.insert(0, os.path.abspath('/testbed'))
+
+from nikola.plugins.command.init import CommandInit
+from nikola.__main__ import main
+
+# Create a temporary site
+temp_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp()
+print(f"Creating test site in {temp_dir}")
+
+# Initialize the site
+init_cmd = CommandInit()
+init_cmd.create_empty_site(temp_dir)
+init_cmd.create_configuration(temp_dir)
+
+# Create the directory structure for posts
+posts_dir = os.path.join(temp_dir, 'posts')
+cat1_dir = os.path.join(posts_dir, 'cat1')
+cat2_dir = os.path.join(posts_dir, 'cat2')
+subcat_dir = os.path.join(cat1_dir, 'subcat')
+os.makedirs(cat1_dir, exist_ok=True)
+os.makedirs(cat2_dir, exist_ok=True)
+os.makedirs(subcat_dir, exist_ok=True)
+
+# Create some posts
+def create_post(directory, filename, title, content, category=None):
+    post_path = os.path.join(directory, filename)
+    category_line = f".. category: {category}\n" if category else ".. category: \n"
+    with open(post_path, 'w') as f:
+        f.write(f""".. title: {title}
+.. slug: {title.lower().replace(' ', '-')}
+.. date: 2023-01-01 12:00:00 UTC
+.. tags: 
+{category_line}.. link: 
+.. description: 
+.. type: text
+
+{content}
+""")
+    return post_path
+
+# Create posts in different categories
+create_post(cat1_dir, 'post1.rst', 'Post 1', 'This is post 1 in cat1')
+create_post(cat1_dir, 'post2.rst', 'Post 2', 'This is post 2 in cat1')
+create_post(cat2_dir, 'post3.rst', 'Post 3', 'This is post 3 in cat2')
+create_post(subcat_dir, 'post4.rst', 'Post 4', 'This is post 4 in cat1/subcat')

---- BEGIN FUNCTION #1: execute_bash ----
Description: Execute a bash command in the terminal within a persistent shell session.

### Command Execution
* One command at a time: You can only execute one bash command at a time. If you need to run multiple commands sequentially, use `&&` or `;` to chain them together.
* Persistent session: Commands execute in a persistent shell session where environment variables, virtual environments, and working directory persist between commands.
* Timeout: Commands have a soft timeout of 120 seconds, once that's reached, you have the option to continue or interrupt the command (see section below for details)

### Running and Interacting with Processes
* Long running commands: For commands that may run indefinitely, run them in the background and redirect output to a file, e.g. `python3 app.py > server.log 2>&1 &`.
* Interact with running process: If a bash command returns exit code `-1`, this means the process is not yet finished. By setting `is_input` to `true`, you can:
  - Send empty `command` to retrieve additional logs
  - Send text (set `command` to the text) to STDIN of the running process
  - Send control commands like `C-c` (Ctrl+C), `C-d` (Ctrl+D), or `C-z` (Ctrl+Z) to interrupt the process

### Best Practices
* Directory verification: Before creating new directories or files, first verify the parent directory exists and is the correct location.
* Directory management: Try to maintain working directory by using absolute paths and avoiding excessive use of `cd`.

### Output Handling
* Output truncation: If the output exceeds a maximum length, it will be truncated before being returned.

Parameters:
  (1) command (string, required): The bash command to execute. Can be empty string to view additional logs when previous exit code is `-1`. Can be `C-c` (Ctrl+C) to interrupt the currently running process. Note: You can only execute one bash command at a time. If you need to run multiple commands sequentially, you can use `&&` or `;` to chain them together.
  (2) is_input (string, optional): If True, the command is an input to the running process. If False, the command is a bash command to be executed in the terminal. Default is False.
Allowed values: [`true`, `false`]
---- END FUNCTION #1 ----

<pr_description>
# Query.any() method not working correctly with callable conditions

I'm experiencing an issue with the `any()` method of the `Query` class. It seems like the implementation of the callable and non-callable conditions are swapped.

Here's a simple example that demonstrates the issue:

```python
from tinydb import TinyDB, Query

db = TinyDB('db.json')
User = Query()

# This should work but fails
query = User.followers.any(User.name == 'don')
result = db.search(query)

# This also doesn't work as expected
query = User.followers.any(['don', 'jon'])
result = db.search(query)
```

When I try to use a callable condition with `any()`, it seems to be treating it as a list to check for membership instead of applying the callable to each element. And vice versa - when I pass a list, it's trying to call the list as a function.

I've verified this behavior with different types of queries:

```python
# Should work but doesn't
query = User.followers.any(User.num.matches('\\d+'))

# Should work but doesn't
query = User.followers.any([{'name': 'don'}, {'name': 'john'}])
```

This is strange because the `all()` method seems to work correctly. I think there might be a mix-up in the implementation of the `any()` method.
</pr_description>

    31	class QueryLike(Protocol):
    32	    """
    33	    A typing protocol that acts like a query.
    34	
    35	    Something that we use as a query must have two properties:
    36	
    37	    1. It must be callable, accepting a `Mapping` object and returning a
    38	       boolean that indicates whether the value matches the query, and
    39	    2. it must have a stable hash that will be used for query caching.
    40	
    41	    In addition, to mark a query as non-cacheable (e.g. if it involves
    42	    some remote lookup) it needs to have a method called ``is_cacheable``
    43	    that returns ``False``.
    44	
    45	    This query protocol is used to make MyPy correctly support the query
    46	    pattern that TinyDB uses.
    47	
    48	    See also https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/protocols.html#simple-user-defined-protocols
    49	    """
    50	    def __call__(self, value: Mapping) -> bool: ...
    51	
    52	    def __hash__(self) -> int: ...
    53	
    54	
    55	class QueryInstance:
    56	    """
    57	    A query instance.
    58	
    59	    This is the object on which the actual query operations are performed. The
    60	    :class:`~tinydb.queries.Query` class acts like a query builder and
    61	    generates :class:`~tinydb.queries.QueryInstance` objects which will
    62	    evaluate their query against a given document when called.
    63	
    64	    Query instances can be combined using logical OR and AND and inverted using
    65	    logical NOT.
    66	
    67	    In order to be usable in a query cache, a query needs to have a stable hash
    68	    value with the same query always returning the same hash. That way a query
    69	    instance can be used as a key in a dictionary.
    70	    """
    71	
    72	    def __init__(self, test: Callable[[Mapping], bool], hashval: Optional[Tuple]):
    73	        self._test = test
    74	        self._hash = hashval
    75	
    76	    def is_cacheable(self) -> bool:
    77	        return self._hash is not None
    78	
    79	    def __call__(self, value: Mapping) -> bool:
    80	        """
    81	        Evaluate the query to check if it matches a specified value.
    82	
    83	        :param value: The value to check.
    84	        :return: Whether the value matches this query.
    85	        """
    86	        return self._test(value)
    87	
    88	    def __hash__(self) -> int:
    89	        # We calculate the query hash by using the ``hashval`` object which
    90	        # describes this query uniquely, so we can calculate a stable hash
    91	        # value by simply hashing it
    92	        return hash(self._hash)
    93	
    94	    def __repr__(self):
    95	        return 'QueryImpl{}'.format(self._hash)
    96	
    97	    def __eq__(self, other: object):
    98	        if isinstance(other, QueryInstance):
    99	            return self._hash == other._hash
   100	
   101	        return False
   102	
   103	    # --- Query modifiers -----------------------------------------------------
   104	
   105	    def __and__(self, other: 'QueryInstance') -> 'QueryInstance':
   106	        # We use a frozenset for the hash as the AND operation is commutative
   107	        # (a & b == b & a) and the frozenset does not consider the order of
   108	        # elements
   109	        if self.is_cacheable() and other.is_cacheable():
   110	            hashval = ('and', frozenset([self._hash, other._hash]))
   111	        else:
   112	            hashval = None
   113	        return QueryInstance(lambda value: self(value) and other(value), hashval)
   114	
   115	    def __or__(self, other: 'QueryInstance') -> 'QueryInstance':
   116	        # We use a frozenset for the hash as the OR operation is commutative
   117	        # (a | b == b | a) and the frozenset does not consider the order of
   118	        # elements
   119	        if self.is_cacheable() and other.is_cacheable():
   120	            hashval = ('or', frozenset([self._hash, other._hash]))
   121	        else:
   122	            hashval = None
   123	        return QueryInstance(lambda value: self(value) or other(value), hashval)
   124	
   125	    def __invert__(self) -> 'QueryInstance':
   126	        hashval = ('not', self._hash) if self.is_cacheable() else None
   127	        return QueryInstance(lambda value: not self(value), hashval)

   130	class Query(QueryInstance):
   131	    """
   132	    TinyDB Queries.
   133	
   134	    Allows building queries for TinyDB databases. There are two main ways of
   135	    using queries:
   136	
   137	    1) ORM-like usage:
   138	
   139	    >>> User = Query()
   140	    >>> db.search(User.name == 'John Doe')
   141	    >>> db.search(User['logged-in'] == True)
   142	
   143	    2) Classical usage:
   144	
   145	    >>> db.search(where('value') == True)
   146	
   147	    Note that ``where(...)`` is a shorthand for ``Query(...)`` allowing for
   148	    a more fluent syntax.
   149	
   150	    Besides the methods documented here you can combine queries using the
   151	    binary AND and OR operators:
   152	
   153	    >>> # Binary AND:
   154	    >>> db.search((where('field1').exists()) & (where('field2') == 5))
   155	    >>> # Binary OR:
   156	    >>> db.search((where('field1').exists()) | (where('field2') == 5))
   157	
   158	    Queries are executed by calling the resulting object. They expect to get
   159	    the document to test as the first argument and return ``True`` or
   160	    ``False`` depending on whether the documents match the query or not.
   161	    """
   162	
   163	    def __init__(self) -> None:

   165	        self._path: Tuple[Union[str, Callable], ...] = ()
   166	
   167	        # Prevent empty queries to be evaluated
   168	        def notest(_):
   169	            raise RuntimeError('Empty query was evaluated')

   171	        super().__init__(
   172	            test=notest,
   173	            hashval=(None,)

   176	    def __repr__(self):

   178	
   179	    def __hash__(self):

   182	    def __getattr__(self, item: str):
   183	        # Generate a new query object with the new query path
   184	        # We use type(self) to get the class of the current query in case
   185	        # someone uses a subclass of ``Query``
   186	        query = type(self)()

   188	        # Now we add the accessed item to the query path ...
   189	        query._path = self._path + (item,)

   191	        # ... and update the query hash
   192	        query._hash = ('path', query._path) if self.is_cacheable() else None

   194	        return query

   196	    def __getitem__(self, item: str):

   200	        # the name as a method name first, only then call our ``__getattr__``

   202	        # calling e.g. ``Query()['test']`` will always generate a query for a
   203	        # document's ``test`` field instead of returning a reference to the
   204	        # ``Query.test`` method

   207	    def _generate_test(

   214	        Generate a query based on a test function that first resolves the query

<think>
After examining the code, I can see the issue in the `any()` method implementation. Looking at lines 415-420 in `queries.py`, the implementation of the `any()` method has the conditions for callable and non-callable swapped:

```python
def any(self, cond: Union[QueryInstance, List[Any]]) -> QueryInstance:
    if callable(cond):
        def test(value):
            return is_sequence(value) and any(e in cond for e in value)
    else:
        def test(value):
            return is_sequence(value) and any(cond(e) for e in value)
```

The issue is that when `cond` is callable (like a query), it's using `e in cond` which treats `cond` as a collection to check membership. But when `cond` is not callable (like a list), it's using `cond(e)` which tries to call `cond` as a function.

This is exactly the opposite of what should happen. Let's create a script to reproduce the issue:

from tinydb import TinyDB, Query
import os
import json

# Create a test database
if os.path.exists('db.json'):
    os.remove('db.json')

db = TinyDB('db.json')

# Insert some test data
db.insert({
    'followers': [
        {'name': 'don', 'num': '123'},
        {'name': 'john', 'num': 'abc'}
    ]
})

User = Query()

print("Testing with callable condition (should work but fails):")
try:
    query = User.followers.any(User.name == 'don')
    result = db.search(query)
    print(f"Result: {result}")
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")

print("\nTesting with list condition (should work but fails):")
try:
    query = User.followers.any(['don', 'jon'])
    result = db.search(query)
    print(f"Result: {result}")
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")

print("\nTesting with regex condition (should work but fails):")
try:
    query = User.followers.any(User.num.matches('\\d+'))
    result = db.search(query)
    print(f"Result: {result}")
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")

print("\nTesting with list of dictionaries (should work but fails):")
try:
    query = User.followers.any([{'name': 'don'}, {'name': 'john'}])
    result = db.search(query)
    print(f"Result: {result}")
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")

def any(self, cond: Union[QueryInstance, List[Any]]) -> QueryInstance:
        """
        Check if a condition is met by any document in a list,
        where a condition can also be a sequence (e.g. list).

        >>> Query().f1.any(Query().f2 == 1)

        Matches::

            {'f1': [{'f2': 1}, {'f2': 0}]}

        >>> Query().f1.any([1, 2, 3])

        Matches::

            {'f1': [1, 2]}
            {'f1': [3, 4, 5]}

        :param cond: Either a query that at least one document has to match or
                     a list of which at least one document has to be contained
                     in the tested document.
        """
        if callable(cond):
            def test(value):
                return is_sequence(value) and any(e in cond for e in value)
        else:
            def test(value):
                return is_sequence(value) and any(cond(e) for e in value)

        return self._generate_test(
            lambda value: test(value),
            ('any', self._path, freeze(cond))
        )

def any(self, cond: Union[QueryInstance, List[Any]]) -> QueryInstance:
        """
        Check if a condition is met by any document in a list,
        where a condition can also be a sequence (e.g. list).

        >>> Query().f1.any(Query().f2 == 1)

        Matches::

            {'f1': [{'f2': 1}, {'f2': 0}]}

        >>> Query().f1.any([1, 2, 3])

        Matches::

            {'f1': [1, 2]}
            {'f1': [3, 4, 5]}

        :param cond: Either a query that at least one document has to match or
                     a list of which at least one document has to be contained
                     in the tested document.
        """
        if callable(cond):
            def test(value):
                return is_sequence(value) and any(cond(e) for e in value)
        else:
            def test(value):
                return is_sequence(value) and any(e in cond for e in value)

        return self._generate_test(
            lambda value: test(value),
            ('any', self._path, freeze(cond))
        )

## Step 5: Think about edge cases

Let's consider some edge cases to make sure our fix handles them correctly:

1. **Empty lists**: What happens if the list in the document is empty?
2. **None values**: What happens if the value is None instead of a list?

---- BEGIN FUNCTION #1: execute_bash ----
Description: Execute a bash command in the terminal within a persistent shell session.

### Command Execution
* One command at a time: You can only execute one bash command at a time. If you need to run multiple commands sequentially, use `&&` or `;` to chain them together.
* Persistent session: Commands execute in a persistent shell session where environment variables, virtual environments, and working directory persist between commands.
* Timeout: Commands have a soft timeout of 120 seconds, once that's reached, you have the option to continue or interrupt the command (see section below for details)

### Running and Interacting with Processes
* Long running commands: For commands that may run indefinitely, run them in the background and redirect output to a file, e.g. `python3 app.py > server.log 2>&1 &`.
* Interact with running process: If a bash command returns exit code `-1`, this means the process is not yet finished. By setting `is_input` to `true`, you can:
  - Send empty `command` to retrieve additional logs
  - Send text (set `command` to the text) to STDIN of the running process
  - Send control commands like `C-c` (Ctrl+C), `C-d` (Ctrl+D), or `C-z` (Ctrl+Z) to interrupt the process

### Best Practices
* Directory verification: Before creating new directories or files, first verify the parent directory exists and is the correct location.
* Directory management: Try to maintain working directory by using absolute paths and avoiding excessive use of `cd`.

### Output Handling
* Output truncation: If the output exceeds a maximum length, it will be truncated before being returned.

Parameters:
  (1) command (string, required): The bash command to execute. Can be empty string to view additional logs when previous exit code is `-1`. Can be `C-c` (Ctrl+C) to interrupt the currently running process. Note: You can only execute one bash command at a time. If you need to run multiple commands sequentially, you can use `&&` or `;` to chain them together.
  (2) is_input (string, optional): If True, the command is an input to the running process. If False, the command is a bash command to be executed in the terminal. Default is False.
Allowed values: [`true`, `false`]
